So some words of the real-world. You can change the IOPS of a volume on the fly, but from my experience, for big database volumes this takes hours, even days. AWS takes care you can use your provisioned IOPS and does the sync to faster storage at the background with what extra IOPS they have left. Also there is absolutely no SLA for this process - it will eventually happen. 
So if you count on CloudWath metrics for this change (as stated in C), you will still get angry customers. If you would do it planned and 2 days before, this might work.
So I go for read replica, because question is about *reporting* at month end. This can be scheduled during low-load time the night before the first high-load day.

I go for C as well as creating Read Replica can cause some performance issues:
"When you create a read replica, Amazon RDS takes a DB snapshot of your source DB instance and begins replication. As a result, you experience a brief I/O suspension on your source DB instance while the DB snapshot occurs. The I/O suspension typically lasts about one minute. You can avoid the I/O suspension if the source DB instance is a Multi-AZ deployment, because in that case the snapshot is taken from the secondary DB instance."
It's nothing about multi-az in this question so it can take some risk.
